# require(toFail:)

**Instance Method**

Creates a dependency relationship between the gesture recognizer and another gesture recognizer when the objects are created.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor func require(toFail otherGestureRecognizer: UIGestureRecognizer)
```

## Parameters

- **otherGestureRecognizer**: Another gesture-recognizer object (an instance of a subclass of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer]).

## Discussion

This method works fine when gesture recognizers aren’t created elsewhere in the app — or in a framework — and the set of gesture recognizers remains the same. If you need to set up failure requirements lazily or in different view hierarchies, use [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizerDelegate/gestureRecognizer(_:shouldRequireFailureOf:)] and [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizerDelegate/gestureRecognizer(_:shouldBeRequiredToFailBy:)] instead. (Note that the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/shouldRequireFailure(of:)] and [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/shouldBeRequiredToFail(by:)] methods let subclasses define class-wide failure requirements.)

This method creates a relationship with another gesture recognizer that delays the current gesture recognizer’s transition out of [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/State-swift.enum/possible]. The state that the current gesture recognizer transitions to depends on what happens with `otherGestureRecognizer`:

- If `otherGestureRecognizer` transitions to [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/State-swift.enum/failed], the current gesture recognizer transitions to its normal next state.
- If `otherGestureRecognizer` transitions to [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/State-swift.enum/recognized] or [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/State-swift.enum/began], the current gesture recognizer transitions to [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIGestureRecognizer/State-swift.enum/failed].

An example where this method might be called is when you want a single-tap gesture require that a double-tap gesture fail.

## Related Documentation

- **shouldBeRequiredToFail(by:)**: Overridden to indicate that the receiver should be required to fail by the specified gesture recognizer.
- **shouldRequireFailure(of:)**: Overridden to indicate that the receiver requires the specified gesture recognizer to fail.
